text:
"I knew it!" Porfiry exclaimed, clearly frustrated. "He’s not telling his own story," he muttered, almost to himself, before his gaze landed back on Raskolnikov. For a moment, he seemed so focused on Nikolay that he forgot about Raskolnikov, and it threw him off a bit. 

"My dear Rodion Romanovitch, I’m sorry!" he rushed over. "You can’t stay here. It’s not good for you. I’ll... well, surprise! Goodbye!" He took Raskolnikov by the arm and led him to the door.

"I guess you didn’t see that coming?" Raskolnikov said, feeling a bit braver even though he was still processing everything.

"You didn’t expect it either, buddy. Look at your hand shaking! He-he!" 

"You’re shaking too, Porfiry Petrovitch!" 

"Yeah, I didn’t see this coming," he admitted. 

They were at the door now, and Porfiry was eager for Raskolnikov to leave. 

"Aren’t you going to show me your little surprise?" Raskolnikov asked, with a hint of sarcasm. 

"Look at him, his teeth are chattering! You’re quite the ironic one! Until next time!" 

"I think we can say goodbye for now!" 

"That’s up to God," Porfiry replied with a strange smile.
